It's hard to write honestly of traditional cultures, for good or ill.

I say "hard" because of the U.S. role in propping up certain regimes -- fossilizing even the cruelest power centers abroad, all too often to facilitate the interests of Corporate America investments. Thus bin Laden and his crew chafed and angered over the subsidies, military gifts, and other support given by the U.S. similarly to Israel as to the despotic regimes in Egypt and Saudi Arabia.

Maybe Corporate America introduces liberalization of societies -- certainly so for commercial reasons -- but as we may cheer this, we might also weigh how parallel globalism policies force massive social dislocation and change -- mass migration from villages and small farms to montrous cities. These -- in Cairo, Riyadh, and Teheran (under U.S. stooge Shah and after) fill with lots who are not especially happy campers, lost as literally millions are: "Can't Go Home Again" to the old, but can't get access to the new consumerism, or educational institutions, or decent jobs in the new, mega-urban cultures.

So while I value your attempts to report from there, I'd value it much more if you factored in the information on how U.S. subsidies tilt those places and regimes also to corruption, nepotism, privilege, and militarism that only turn the masses more and more against us.

Too bad we don't have a Peace Prize Prez with any actual peace policies.

No doubt, the severe winter weather has made many more people skeptical of man-caused global warming.

But, when prominent scientists admit there has been no statistically significant warming for some time, when they admit significant errors in their reports, people have every right to be skeptical.

The AGW proponents have said the science is settled. Now, we find that it isn't. There are holes in their theories or legitimate questions about their computer models.

This doesn't mean there's no warming somewhere. What it clearly means is that the AGW proponents must know what they're talking about, that ALL of the variables are correctly factored in and that they should stop sarcastically dismissing skeptics as nuts.

If one wants to refer to refer to a scientist consensus, the closest you can come to is the Institute of Physics, with a worldwide membership of over 36,000, the leading communicator of physics-related science to all audiences, from specialists through to government and the general public.

Their scathing critic of the CRU, reproduced below, shows that professionals are very skeptical about the claims of global warming.

Current surface and satellite data shows in fact to anyone interested enough to look for data that since 2002 we are in a period of global cooling.

The measured data shows that the global temperature changed between 1970 and 2010 virtually identically with the way it changed between 1910 and 1950, a growth of about 0.65C in each 40 year period. In the recent period there were massive CO2 emissions, in the early one very few.

An independent site which aggregates many temperature databases is for instance

http://www.woodfortrees.org...

These facts were admitted in the recent interview with the BBC by Phil Jones.

http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/8511670.stm and
http://www.dailymail.co.uk...

The Institute of Physics has testified last week to the British Parliament that

2. The CRU e-mails as published on the internet provide prima facie evidence of determined and co-ordinated refusals to comply with honourable scientific traditions and freedom of information law. The principle that scientists should be willing to expose their ideas and results to independent testing and replication by others, which requires the open exchange of data, procedures and materials, is vital…

3. It is important to recognise that there are two completely different categories of data set that are involved in the CRU e-mail exchanges:

· those compiled from direct instrumental measurements of land and ocean surface temperatures such as the CRU, GISS and NOAA data sets; and

· historic temperature reconstructions from measurements of ‘proxies’, for example, tree-rings.

4. The second category relating to proxy reconstructions are the basis for the conclusion that 20th century warming is unprecedented. Published reconstructions may represent only a part of the raw data available and may be sensitive to the choices made and the statistical techniques used. Different choices, omissions or statistical processes may lead to different conclusions. This possibility was evidently the reason behind some of the (rejected) requests for further information.

5. The e-mails reveal doubts as to the reliability of some of the reconstructions and raise questions as to the way in which they have been represented; for example, the apparent suppression, in graphics widely used by the IPCC, of proxy results for recent decades that do not agree with contemporary instrumental temperature measurements.

6. There is also reason for concern at the intolerance to challenge displayed in the e-mails. This impedes the process of scientific ‘self correction’, which is vital to the integrity of the scientific process as a whole, and not just to the research itself. In that context, those CRU e-mails relating to the peer-review process suggest a need for a review of its adequacy and objectivity as practised in this field and its potential vulnerability to bias or manipulation.

7. Fundamentally, we consider it should be inappropriate for the verification of the integrity of the scientific process to depend on appeals to Freedom of Information legislation. Nevertheless, the right to such appeals has been shown to be necessary. The e-mails illustrate the possibility of networks of like-minded researchers effectively excluding newcomers...

First, win the nomenclature war. If we stick with "Hot Hot Planet" warnings to a population with the attention span of an American Idol or Eurovision contestant, we should anticipate problems. This article is full of references to climate change that is terrific, but that has not how things have been been presented to the masses. No one but a few laygeeks appreciates the impact on prevailing winds or principles of chaos. People have been expecting Miami temperatures in Buffalo, and they expected them last year.

Second, avoid distractions by spending money on communications experts. Let the scientists focus; let them be their ivory-towered, insular selves. If they were better public speakers, they'd have become lawyers. If they were better actors, then they would have become cable news pundits. If they were completely perfect, they'd be John McPhee, one of the few willing to try to translate valid science to the rest of us idiots. I'm good with science being the best revenge, but there must be money and time available to extract it.

Given the measured data showing that in spite of the massive recent emissions of CO2 the weather has been reproducing in the last 4 decades its behavior between 1910 and 1950 (including a last decade of cooling) the best strategy now is to put a major part of climate study funds into collection of climate data through many channels - earth, balloons, satellites), open dissemination of such data including the precise justification of each correction, as well as an equally careful and open study of past climate data, with particular emphasis on finding, rather than hiding, similarities between present and past weather patterns.

Toy models which give outlandish predictions while they cannot explain the observed lack of correlation between measured temperatures and CO2 levels should be treated and funded as, well, toy models.

The IPCC cannot fulfill a guiding role in climate science since its very name and reason to exist is climate change. The measured data shows that the climate has not changed recently. The temperature continues on the very long run the historical trend of 1 deg C/century warming, which makes statements like "The last decade was the warmest in history" irrelevant - that was almost always the case in the last 200 years, high, low or negligible industrial CO2 emissions. The same for the ocean levels, growing at 1ft/century as they always do.

The 2007 Arctic ice cap melt (the ice has since almost returned) was similar to a well documented one in 1922. The Nov 2, 1922 Washington Post had the headline

Arctic Ocean Getting Warm; Seals Vanish and Icebergs Melt

(check the archives for ice melt 1922).

Under these circumstances, how could the IPCC be trusted to present the scientific data showing that the climate changes as it did before the recent growth in CO2 emissions.

In the least, it should be replaced with an IPCW dedicated to climate watch rather than climate change...
